instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
Hello, I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which has been through a little, but ALOT. I first got the board and noticed it had water damage across different parts of the board, mainly backlight, and some parts of the thunderbolt hardware as well. However, the CPU has a tiny little chip on the PCB of the CPU, on the edge of it. No bigger than a small grain of rice, it is fact though, chipped.

CPU would not turn on due to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> issues, however I managed to fix them. After that, it was near impossible for the board to fully power on. It would power on, but show symptoms of a bad BIOS or SPI ROM issue, like with the actual chip itself. I replaced the chip, flashed a whole new clean BIOS, clean ME, and the board did in fact power on. However heres the strange part. Im now booting Apple Diagnostics, and its telling me the thunderbolt controller, and other parts of it are not functioning. I thought this was weird because im using a TBT to HDMI adapter while testing. I then tried booting my test OS, and it would get stuck near the end of the loading bar and never finish loading. I then proceeded to run Apple Service Diagnostics OS, and ran it in verbose mode. I then noticed it would panic with "ME DETECT" "FAILURE MISSING ME"

ME problem, ok then, lets reflash. Reflashed with donor board bios, and cleaned me, and same issue. Used ANOTHER, donor board bios chip, and bios with clean ME, same issue.

So here we are, any ideas? Ive also attached photos.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message: Couldnt upload for some reason, heres the panic

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message: Self thinking, would an <SIGNAL>HDA_SDOUT</SIGNAL> high signal cause this? Ive read somewhere that this is an disable ME chip?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
I faced few times with mentioned symptom on 3435 and 00165 boards; couldn't get it fixed.

You can play around <TRANSISTOR>Q1920</TRANSISTOR>, remove <RESISTOR>R1921</RESISTOR> first.

But you should be sure the ME region has been properly cleaned.
Did you use Medusa programmer?
If not, try this dump.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/13uGw4JJqRRMxwH7KOdDJmFpOcIhgzsX5/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
I use the "old school" way of doing this. I did not mention it but J6100 is removed as well. I use a ch341a programmer, and a adapter board for the flash chips. 

I will use your ROM file. If that does not work, I will experiment with <TRANSISTOR>Q1920</TRANSISTOR> and aliases and report back.

Im so tired of BIOS issues, ive had 6 boards out of 8 with them this week :rolleyes:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
Okay, wow, so now the board is really weird. MOSI and CLK are now 0V. I literally just had a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that I thought was a programming mode or something, but was a BIOS issue. Is this a BIOS issue also? Im so confused :LOL::cry:

EDIT: I did nothing to it, I just took it out of the case it was in and wanted to see how it would turn on without anything plugged into it except charger and USB (for activity)

EDIT 2: SPI_DESCRIPTOR_OVERRIDE_L is high, im going to say SMC issue? but why? Very interesting

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
Some BIOS data lines drop to 0V as nornal, when PCH accesses SPI chip.

Please do not mix boards in the same post.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
I was not mixing them, I just stated I had a problem like this earlier but not related. A working <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> should have 3v3 on all pins no? even when pch is accessing spi chip?

If what i stated above is not the case, bad pch possibly? what about the SPI_DESCRIPTOR_OVERRIDE_L signal? what does this indicate?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
"A working <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> should have 3v3 on all pins no?"
NO.
"Some BIOS data lines drop to 0V as nornal, when PCH accesses SPI chip"

As pull-up resistors are embedded into PCH, is also possible to have broken traces, or series resistors, between SPI chip and PCH.

The mentioned ovveride signal is used when the BIOS is updated by software; like macOS upgrade.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
"Some BIOS data lines drop to 0V as normal, when PCH accesses SPI chip"

These signals are still 0V, complete 0.000 even after "booting", I can reach the EFI and boot selector stage, as well as diagnostics, and they are still 0V.
Would this mean PCH is always accessing SPI chip? Or would it mean something else?

"The mentioned override signal is used when the BIOS is updated by software; like macOS upgrade."
Hmm, Im beginning to think this is an SMC issue more and more, could the SMC be pulling the MOSI and CLK signals low?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
I don't understand what is not clear there.
Did you even check SPI signals into working board?
No matters which model is, I 'm sure you have an working MacBook board in the shop.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
You were right, im overthinking everything at this point sorry. Yes SPI is normal and SPI_DESCRIPTOR_OVERRIDE_L is normal. Ive flashed your BIOS file youve provided and now the board does not start.  However it would sometimes do this before as well. It now is taking 228 Mah, with IO board and cable attached. However it slowly will take more Mah, 5 min has gone by with it still being plugged in and its now at 235 mah. Im going to rule this as a CPU on its last leg.

EDIT: Just btw, we have fan spin, Vcore @ 1.7, and cpu gets warm, and MOSI and CLK are 0v, <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is low as well, and CPU is around 35 ohms and declining in diode mode

EDIT 2: In the schematic, PCH LESS MODE aka <RESISTOR>R0631</RESISTOR>, is no stuff. For experimental purposes, Im going to add a 1k resistor to that and see what happens. IF it does nothing, I will also put <RESISTOR>R0640</RESISTOR>, which is SAFE MODE BOOT, just for safety ;)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
Board cannot boot with <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
It should go high before PCH accesses BIOS.
Check <SIGNAL>CPU_VCSST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL> and pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>VR_READY</SIGNAL> is a solid 1.05V
VCSST is a solid 1.05V
<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is 3.4V
Pin 3 is 0V

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> other voltages are
Pin 1 - 3.4V
Pin 2 - 3.3V
Pin 3 - 0V
Pin 4 - GND
Pin 5 - 3.4V
Pin 6 - 3.4V
Pin 7 - Pin 5
Pin 8 - 3.4V

Going to replace <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, as it seems like somethings wrong with it. Pin 3 is a solid 0.000, so should be promising its the chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
If pins 5 & 6 are high, pin 3 should be high too.
Check for corrosion, replace the chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, same issue. Found Pin 2 low, found <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL> are both 1.05V. Is this from the CPU or <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>?

EDIT: <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is 3.3V, and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> was kinda messed up, took little heat to remove and little time, also Pin 5 is half gone but still has continuity, and is 3.3V as well as Pin 7, and 6.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL>/READY have both correct value.
Pin 2/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> is pulled-up to <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL>; did you check <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR>?

"If pins 5 & 6 are high, pin 3 should be high too."
Remember that.
Check for broken traces and bad solders.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message: Yes, I replaced <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR> too just to be sure. Replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> the second time just to be sure, and removed <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR>, and got 3.3V on Pin 3, however when putting the resistor back on I get a solid 0.000 now :unsure:. Im confused on this one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
Seems to have a PCH issue, like sinking too much current on <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>.
Check diode mode to ground there; compare with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
1.5 M ohms at Pin 3, good working board is reading about 9 M ohms

2.5 M ohms at <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>, working board is at around 9 to 9.5 M ohms

Should I try to inject voltage at <RESISTOR>R1962</RESISTOR>? Or is that an actual signal not a solid voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message:
I asked about diode mode, not ohm.
Check diode mode to ground in both directions.
Heat PCH with quality flux; may be just accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message: Finally, I had to order more solder balls to reball an donor board cpu, but board is working now. I reflowed CPU and PCH first and still same issue, so I pulled the CPU and I noticed some of the solder balls were just weird looking, or partially missing. Going over it with the soldering iron fixed all the weird looking spots, and I replaced CPU. This is my first successful cpu replacement for an air board! Thanks for helping me

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ME issue??
threads.message: Good job, not easy at all.
